sen.j: 織田 常松（おだ じょうしょう、生没年不詳）は、室町時代の武将。
sen.e: Josho ODA (year of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in Muromachi period.
Josho ODA (year of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 常松は戒名であり、正式には伊勢守入道常松という。
sen.e: Josho was his kaimyo (posthumous Buddhist name) and his official name was Ise no kami nyudo josho.

sen.j: 『前野家文書』「武功夜話」によると織田郷広と同一人物か？
sen.e: According to 'Bukoyawa', the main family record of "Maeno Family's notes," he and Satohiro ODA were the same person.

sen.j: 尾張国守護・斯波義将に仕え、1400年（應永7年）、甲斐将教に代わり斯波義将より、尾張国守護代へ任じられた。
sen.e: Serving Yoshimasa SHIBA, Shugo (provincial military governor) of Owari Province, he was appointed as shugodai by Yoshimasa to take the place of Masanori KAI in 1400.
Serving Yoshimasa SHIBA, Owari no kuni Shugo (provincial military governor of Owari Province), Josho was appointed as Owari no kuni Shugodai by Yoshimasa to take the place of Masanori KAI in 1400.
sen.cmt: Shugo (provincial military governor) of Owari Province > Shugo (provincial military governor) of Owari Provincehe > Joshoshugodai > Owari no kuni Shugodai
sen.e: Serving Yoshimasa SHIBA, Owari no kuni Shugo (provincial military governor of Owari Province), Josho was appointed as Owari no kuni Shugodai by Yoshimasa to take the place of Masanori KAI in 1400.

sen.j: 常松は斯波氏在京の守護代であり、兄弟とされる織田常竹が代官として、尾張を在地支配をしていた。
sen.e: Josho was an acting military governor when the Shiba clan stayed in Kyoto and Jochiku ODA, possibly Josho's brother, ruled Owari Province as an acting deputy military governor.
sen.cmt: ここでの「代官」は守護代の代理の意と思われます。それを意味する「小守護代」は定訳がありますが、そのまま使用すると分かりにくいと判断しました。
sen.e: Josho was Shugodai when the Shiba clan stayed in Kyoto and Jochiku ODA, possibly Josho's brother, ruled Owari Province as an acting deputy military governor.
Josho was Shugodai when the Shiba clan stayed in Kyoto and Jochiku ODA, possibly Josho's brother, ruled Owari Province as an acting deputy military governor.

sen.j: 応永6年（1399年）の応永の乱が起こると、常松は主君の尾張国守護・斯波義将に従軍したという（常松の肖像賛には「昔爾祖合戦泉堺、蓋代之功、殆百年耳」とあったという）。
sen.e: When the Oei War broke out in 1399, Josho reportedly sided with his lord Yoshimasa SHIBA, Shugo of Owari Province (the phrase '昔爾祖合戦泉堺、蓋代之功、殆百年耳' was added to Josho's portrait).
sen.cmt: 「昔・・・」の文言は意味が判明しなかったので、そのままにしました。
sen.e: When the Oei War broke out in 1399, Josho reportedly sided with his lord Yoshimasa SHIBA, Owari no kuni Shugo (the phrase '昔爾祖合戦泉堺、蓋代之功、殆百年耳' was added to Josho's portrait).
sen.cmt: Shugo of Owari Province > Owari no kuni Shugo
sen.e: When the Oei War broke out in 1399, Josho reportedly sided with his lord Yoshimasa SHIBA, Owari no kuni Shugo (the phrase '昔爾祖合戦泉堺、蓋代之功、殆百年耳' was added to Josho's portrait).

sen.j: 「織田伊勢入道所労以外聞」とあり、正長元年（1428年）頃、常松は病に侵されたとされる。
sen.e: There is a phrase '織田伊勢入道所労以外聞' (=It is rumored that Oda Ise nyudo is sick) in one document, which phrase indicates that he was taken with illness around 1428.
sen.cmt: 他の情報ソースによると、この文言は「満済准后日記」に記載されているそうですが、ここでは one document としました。

sen.j: 醍醐寺住職の満済が常松の所に見舞いの使者を送った際、織田弾正忠という者が応対したという。
sen.e: When Mansai, chief priest of Daigo-ji Temple, dispatched his envoy to the sick Josho, a person called Danjo-no-jo ODA reportedly received him.

sen.j: 永享3年（1431年）『建内記』には「織田故伊勢入道尾張国守護代」とある。
sen.e: The record of 1431 in "Kenna ki" (a diary describing about social conditions in the middle of the Muromachi period) includes the phrase '織田故伊勢入道尾張国守護代' (the late Ise nyudo, shugodai of Owari Province).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外処置・直後の文言と整合させるため、括弧内の補足に「織田」は含めませんでした。

sen.j: 故伊勢入道とは常松のことされ、正長年間～永享年間頃に常松は死去したと思われる。
sen.e: 故伊勢入道 (the late Ise nyudo) can be identified as Josho, who is believed to have died between the Shocho era (1428) and the Eikyo era (1429-1440).

sen.j: 後に清洲織田家（織田大和守家）の織田敏定が厳中和尚に「織田勢州太守常松居士号秀峯肖像」を描かせたというが、現存していない。
sen.e: Later, Toshisada ODA, of the Kyosu Oda family (the Oda Yamato no Kami family) asked 厳中 Osho priest to paint Josho's portrait called 織田勢州太守常松居士号秀峯肖像, but it is not extant.
sen.cmt: ・肖像の名前は訳しようがないので、そのままとしました。・「厳中」の読みは不明でした。
sen.e: Later, Toshisada ODA, of the Kyosu Oda family (the Oda Yamato no Kami family) asked Genchu Osho priest to paint Josho's portrait called 織田勢州太守常松居士号秀峯肖像, but it is not extant.
